name: Swipe: CompTIA Linux+ and Linux Pro (EN)

meta.source: Generated by AI Assistant (current, CompTIA Linux+ focus)

fragen.frage: In Linux, 'ext4' is a common and modern file system that supports journaling.
fragen.erklaerung: True! ext4 (fourth extended filesystem) is the de facto standard for many Linux distributions. Journaling improves data integrity in case of system crashes.

fragen.frage: The numeric file permission '755' for a directory means that the owner has full rights, while the group and others only have read rights.
fragen.erklaerung: False — '755' means: owner (7=rwx) has full rights; group (5=rx) and others (5=rx) have read and execute rights (i.e., they can enter the directory and list its contents), but no write rights.

fragen.frage: The 'ls -l' command displays a detailed list of files and directories, including permissions, owner, group membership, and file size.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-l' option (long listing format) is essential for detailed information on filesystem objects. It is a frequently used command in Linux administration.

fragen.frage: A 'zombie process' in Linux is a process that is still actively consuming CPU cycles but no longer responding to input.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A zombie process (defunct) has finished its execution and released all resources, but its parent process has not yet collected its exit status. It no longer consumes CPU time but occupies an entry in the process table.

fragen.frage: On Debian-based Linux systems like Ubuntu, the 'yum' command is used to install, update, and remove packages.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'yum' (Yellowdog Updater, Modified) is used on Red Hat-based systems (e.g., CentOS, Fedora). On Debian-based systems, 'apt' or 'apt-get' are used.

fragen.frage: The first line `#!/bin/bash` in a shell script is called a shebang and specifies the interpreter that should execute the script.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The shebang is crucial for the operating system to know which program (e.g., Bash, Python) should be used to execute the script when called directly as an executable file.

fragen.frage: The command 'chmod +x file.sh' makes a script executable.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '+x' option adds execute permission for the owner, group, and others. This is a fundamental step to make shell scripts executable.

fragen.frage: The root directory in Linux is represented by '/'.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The root directory is the topmost level of the Linux filesystem hierarchy and the starting point for all other directories and files.

fragen.frage: The command 'ps aux' displays all running processes on the system, including those belonging to other users.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'ps aux' is a commonly used combination of options to get a complete overview of processes running on a Linux system, including the user who started the process.

fragen.frage: The 'grep' command is used to edit the content of a file.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'grep' (global regular expression print) is used to search for and display text patterns in files. Editors like 'vi', 'nano', or 'emacs' are used to edit files.

fragen.frage: A hard link to a file creates a copy of the file with a different name.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A hard link is an additional directory entry for a file. It points to the same inode as the original file; no new file is created or copied. All hard links to a file are equivalent.

fragen.frage: The 'sudo' command allows a normal user to execute commands as root or another user.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'sudo' (superuser do) is an important security feature in Linux, as it allows the execution of administrative commands without direct root login and can be logged in detail.

fragen.frage: The 'mv' command in Linux is used exclusively for moving files.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The 'mv' command can also be used to rename files or directories. If the source and destination are on the same filesystem and the destination is a new name, the file is renamed.

fragen.frage: A mount point is a directory to which a file system is attached to make its contents accessible.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Without mounting, a file system (e.g., a hard disk partition or a USB drive) cannot access its data in Linux.

fragen.frage: The command 'kill -9 PID' sends a signal that gives a process the opportunity to terminate cleanly.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'kill -9' (SIGKILL) is a hard termination that gives the process no opportunity to terminate cleanly or save data. This should only be used as a last resort. 'kill -15' (SIGTERM) allows a graceful termination.

fragen.frage: The '$PATH' environment variable contains a list of directories where the shell searches for executable commands.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '$' symbol is used before the variable name to access the content of the variable. Without '$', the variable name itself would be used.

fragen.frage: A Linux system can only have a single runlevel (Systemd Target).
fragen.erklaerung: False — Linux systems have different runlevels (SysVinit) or Systemd Targets (systemd) that represent different operating states, e.g., single-user mode, multi-user mode without network, multi-user mode with network, and GUI. The default runlevel is usually the graphical multi-user mode.

fragen.frage: The 'useradd' command is used to change the group of an existing user.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'useradd' is used to create **new** user accounts. To change the group of an existing user, use 'usermod -g GROUP USER' or 'usermod -G ADDITIONAL_GROUP USER'.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/passwd' file stores encrypted user passwords.
fragen.erklaerung: False — '/etc/passwd' stores user information such as username, UID, GID, and home directory, but the passwords themselves (encrypted) are stored in the more secure '/etc/shadow' file.

fragen.frage: The 'df -h' command displays the free and used disk space of file systems in human-readable format.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'df' (disk free) with the '-h' (human-readable) option is an indispensable tool for monitoring disk space on Linux systems.

fragen.frage: The 'systemctl status sshd' command is used to check the status of the Apache web server.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'sshd' is the daemon for the SSH service. To check the status of the Apache web server, one would use 'systemctl status apache2' (Debian/Ubuntu) or 'systemctl status httpd' (RHEL/CentOS).

fragen.frage: The command 'tar -czvf archiv.tar.gz /directory' compresses the directory into a Gzip file and creates an archive.
fragen.erklaerung: True! '-c' stands for create, '-z' for gzip, '-v' for verbose, and '-f' for filename. This is a standard operation for creating compressed archives on Linux.

fragen.frage: A soft link (symbolic link) is a copy of a file stored in a different location.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A soft link is a special file type that points to the path of another file or directory. It is a shortcut, not a copy of the actual data.

fragen.frage: The 'grep -i' command performs a case-sensitive search.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The '-i' option stands for 'ignore case' and performs a case-INsensitive search. A search without this option is case-sensitive by default.

fragen.frage: The 'sticky bit' on a directory prevents files from being deleted or renamed by users other than the owner, even if they have write permissions.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The sticky bit (e.g., set on /tmp) is an important security measure. It allows multiple users to create files in a directory, but only the owner of a file or root can delete or rename that file.

fragen.frage: The 'systemctl start apache2' command starts the Apache web server service on systemd-based systems.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'systemctl' is the primary tool for controlling services under systemd. 'start', 'stop', 'restart', 'status', and 'enable' are commonly used options.

fragen.frage: The '/var/log/syslog' file contains all kernel messages but no information from user applications.
fragen.erklaerung: False — '/var/log/syslog' (or '/var/log/messages' on RHEL systems) contains a mix of system and application messages. It is a central location for most general system logs.

fragen.frage: The 'apt update' command updates the installed packages on a Debian-based system.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'apt update' only updates the package lists (information about available packages and their versions) from the repositories. 'apt upgrade' is required to actually update the installed packages.

fragen.frage: To create a new user in Linux who also gets a home directory, you typically use 'useradd -m USERNAME'.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-m' option stands for 'create home directory'. Without this option, no home directory would be created for the new user.

fragen.frage: The command 'cp -r source destination' copies a directory recursively.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-r' option (recursive) is necessary to copy directories and their entire contents (subdirectories and files). It is not required for single files.

fragen.frage: An inode in Linux contains the actual data of a file.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An inode (Index Node) is a data structure that stores metadata about a file, such as permissions, owner, timestamps, number of hard links, and pointers to the data blocks. The actual file data is in the data blocks.

fragen.frage: The 'free -h' command displays the occupied and free disk space on the hard drive.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'free -h' displays the occupied and free main memory (RAM) and swap space. For hard disk space, the 'df -h' command is used.

fragen.frage: The 'nice' priority of a process can be set to any value by a normal user.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Normal users can only increase the nice priority (make the process 'less important'). To decrease the priority (make the process 'more important'), root privileges are required to prevent system overload by individual users.

fragen.frage: In a Bash script, `$` is used to access the value of a variable, e.g., `$MY_VAR`.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '$' symbol is used before the variable name to access the content of the variable. Without '$', the variable name itself would be used.

fragen.frage: The 'ifconfig' command is the preferred tool for network configuration in modern Linux distributions.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Although 'ifconfig' still exists, the more modern and powerful tool for network configuration in most current Linux distributions is the 'ip' command from the 'iproute2' package.

fragen.frage: The command 'chown user:group file' changes the owner and group of a file.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'chown' (change owner) is an important command for managing file permissions. The colon separates the username from the group.

fragen.frage: A Linux kernel module must always be compiled directly into the kernel and cannot be loaded or unloaded dynamically.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A major advantage of kernel modules is that they can be dynamically loaded ('modprobe') and unloaded ('rmmod') without recompiling the kernel or restarting the system. This increases flexibility and maintainability.

fragen.frage: The '/var/log/messages' file stores detailed information about failed login attempts.
fragen.erklaerung: False — '/var/log/messages' contains general system messages. Failed login attempts are often found in '/var/log/auth.log' (Debian/Ubuntu) or '/var/log/secure' (RHEL/CentOS).

fragen.frage: The 'Advanced Package Tool' (APT) is the primary package management system for Red Hat-based distributions.
fragen.erklaerung: False — APT (and the 'apt'/'apt-get' commands) is the package management system for Debian-based distributions. Red Hat-based systems use 'yum' or 'dnf'.

fragen.frage: The command 'find / -name *.log' searches the entire filesystem for files with the '.log' extension.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'find' is a very powerful command for searching for files and directories based on various criteria in the Linux filesystem.

fragen.frage: The maximum number of primary partitions on an MBR hard disk is 16.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An MBR (Master Boot Record) partition table supports a maximum of 4 primary partitions. To have more partitions, one of the primary partitions must be created as an extended partition, which then contains logical partitions.

fragen.frage: The 'top' command displays a dynamic real-time view of running processes.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'top' is an indispensable tool for process monitoring and system diagnostics, as it shows CPU utilization, memory usage, and running processes live.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/sudoers' file controls which users are allowed to use the 'sudo' command and which commands they can execute.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The 'sudoers' file is crucial for security and permission management in Linux. It should only be edited with 'visudo' to avoid syntax errors.

fragen.frage: The command 'echo Hello World > file.txt' appends the text 'Hello World' to the end of 'file.txt'.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The '>' symbol overwrites the content of 'file.txt' or creates the file if it does not exist. To append text, one would use '>>': 'echo Hello World >> file.txt'.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/hosts' file is used to obtain dynamic IP addresses from a DHCP server.
fragen.erklaerung: False — '/etc/hosts' is a static file used for manually mapping IP addresses to hostnames. DHCP is a protocol that dynamically assigns IP addresses.

fragen.frage: The SUID bit on an executable file causes the program to be executed with the permissions of the file owner, rather than those of the executing user.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The SUID bit (Set User ID) is an important feature often used in system programs like 'passwd' so that normal users can perform privileged operations without being root.

fragen.frage: The Linux kernel is the part of the operating system that directly interacts with hardware and manages basic system resources.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The kernel is the heart of every Linux system. It is responsible for process management, memory management, device management, and handling system calls.

fragen.frage: The 'journalctl' command is used to check syslog service log messages.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'journalctl' is the tool for querying and displaying messages from the systemd journal. On modern Linux systems with systemd, it is the primary tool for log analysis.

fragen.frage: The command 'dpkg -i package.rpm' installs an RPM package on a Debian-based system.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'dpkg -i' installs DEB packages. RPM packages are installed with 'rpm -i' or the DNF/YUM package manager on Red Hat-based systems.

fragen.frage: The command 'cat > file.txt' can be used to type text directly into a file and finish with Ctrl+D.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This procedure redirects standard input (keyboard) to the specified file. It is a quick method for creating small text files directly in the shell.

fragen.frage: A 'swap space' in Linux is exclusively used for temporary storage of kernel data.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Swap space is an area on the hard disk that serves as an extension of physical RAM. It is used when RAM is full to swap out data from less active processes, not just kernel data.

fragen.frage: The 'top -u USERNAME' command displays only the processes of the specified user.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This option is very useful for monitoring the resource usage of individual users and identifying problems caused by their processes.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/group' file contains the passwords of the group members.
fragen.erklaerung: False — '/etc/group' lists groups and their members. Passwords for groups (if any) are stored in the '/etc/gshadow' file.

fragen.frage: A Docker container is a lightweight virtual machine.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Containers share the host system's kernel, while virtual machines have their own complete operating system kernel. Containers are more efficient and start faster than VMs.

fragen.frage: The 'ip a' (or 'ip addr') command is the modern equivalent of 'ifconfig' for displaying network interface information.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'ip a' is part of the 'iproute2' package and provides more comprehensive and detailed information about network interfaces and addressing than the deprecated 'ifconfig' command.

fragen.frage: File permission '644' for a file means that the owner has read and write permissions, while the group and others only have read permissions.
fragen.erklaerung: True! In numeric representation, 6 stands for read (4) and write (2) permissions, and 4 for read permission. This is a common permission for text files.

fragen.frage: The 'grep -r' command searches recursively in subdirectories for a pattern.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-r' option (recursive) is very useful for finding a text pattern in an entire directory structure, which is often necessary when troubleshooting configuration files or log files.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/fstab' file contains the passwords for mounted file systems.
fragen.erklaerung: False — '/etc/fstab' (filesystem table) contains static information about file systems that are to be mounted at system startup, including mount points, file system type, and options. It does not contain passwords.

fragen.frage: The 'crontab -e' command is used to edit firewall rules.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'crontab -e' is used to edit cron jobs (scheduled tasks) for the current user. Firewall rules are managed with tools like 'iptables' or 'firewalld'.

fragen.frage: The 'killall' command sends a signal to all processes with a specific name.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'killall' is more useful than 'kill' when you want to terminate all instances of a program without having to find their individual PIDs (Process IDs).

fragen.frage: A Bash script is always compiled before it is executed.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Bash scripts are interpreted scripts. They are executed line by line by the Bash interpreter without being compiled beforehand. This is a difference from languages like C++ or Java.

fragen.frage: The 'groupdel GROUPNAME' command deletes a group, even if users are still members of that group.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'groupdel' cannot delete a group if it is still the primary group for a user. First, all users must be removed from that primary group, or their primary group must be changed.

fragen.frage: The 'history' command displays a list of the current user's most recently entered commands.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'history' is useful for recalling previous commands and re-executing them. The number of stored commands is controlled by environment variables like HISTSIZE and HISTFILESIZE.

fragen.frage: LVM (Logical Volume Manager) allows dynamically changing the size of partitions while the system is running.
fragen.erklaerung: True! LVM is a powerful tool for flexible storage space management. It allows creating, expanding, and shrinking logical volumes independently of the physical structure of the hard drives.

fragen.frage: The 'route -n' command is used to ping the IP address of a specific host.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'route -n' displays the kernel IP routing table. To ping a host, the 'ping' command is used.

fragen.frage: The SUID bit on a script is a security vulnerability and should be avoided, as it allows for direct privilege escalation.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The SUID bit on scripts (unlike binary programs) is extremely dangerous, as scripts can be easily manipulated and would thus allow uncontrolled privilege escalation. For this reason, many modern Linux systems ignore the SUID bit on scripts.

fragen.frage: The 'modprobe' command is used to remove kernel modules from the kernel.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'modprobe' is used to load kernel modules and their dependencies into the kernel. 'rmmod' is used to remove kernel modules.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/rsyslog.conf' file is the main configuration file for the systemd journal service.
fragen.erklaerung: False — '/etc/rsyslog.conf' is the configuration file for the rsyslog service. The systemd journal is mainly configured via configuration files in the '/etc/systemd/journald.conf.d/' directory or via the main configuration in '/etc/systemd/journald.conf'.

fragen.frage: The 'apt remove package_name' command removes a package and its configuration files from a Debian-based system.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'apt remove' removes a package, but its configuration files remain. To remove both the package AND its configuration files, use 'apt purge package_name'.

fragen.frage: The command 'find . -exec rm {} ;' finds all files in the current directory and its subdirectories and deletes them.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-exec' option executes a command for each found item. '{}' is replaced by the filename and ';' terminates the '-exec' block. This is a powerful but dangerous command.

fragen.frage: A partition designation like '/dev/sdb1' indicates a SATA or SCSI hard drive.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'sd' stands for SCSI disk, which nowadays includes SATA and NVMe drives. 'b' identifies the second hard drive and '1' the first partition on it.

fragen.frage: The command 'nice -n 19 my_process' starts 'my_process' with the highest priority.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A 'nice' priority of 19 is the lowest possible priority (the process is 'very nice' to others). The highest priority is -20. To set the highest priority, root privileges are required.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/skel' file contains scripts that are automatically executed every time a user logs in.
fragen.erklaerung: False — '/etc/skel' (skeleton directory) is a template directory. Its contents are copied into a new user's home directory when that user is created. Login scripts are usually found in the user's home (`.bashrc`, `.profile`) or globally in `/etc/profile`.

fragen.frage: A container is a virtual machine that contains a complete guest operating system.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A virtual machine emulates the entire hardware and has its own kernel and a complete guest operating system. A container virtualizes the operating system and shares the kernel of the host system, making it lighter and faster.

fragen.frage: The command 'iptables -F' deletes all filter rules in the 'filter' table of iptables.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-F' (flush) option is very useful for quickly removing all existing firewall rules to allow reconfiguration or to clear the configuration.

fragen.frage: The SGID bit (Set Group ID) on an executable file causes a program to be executed with the permissions of the owner's group.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Similar to the SUID bit, the SGID bit on executable files allows execution with the permissions of the associated group, which can be useful for certain shared applications.

fragen.frage: The command 'find /etc -type f -mtime +7' searches for all files in the '/etc' directory that were modified within the last 7 days.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The '+7' option with '-mtime' means that the files were modified MORE THAN 7 days ago (i.e., 8 days or older). To find files modified WITHIN the last 7 days, one would use '-mtime -7'.

fragen.frage: The XFS file system is particularly optimized for small partitions with many small files.
fragen.erklaerung: False — XFS is a high-performance journaling file system particularly optimized for large files and file systems (terabyte range) and used in enterprise environments. It can incur overhead for very small files.

fragen.frage: The 'uptime' command shows how long the system has been running and the average system load.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'uptime' is a quick command to get an overview of system availability and current workload, which is useful for quickly diagnosing performance issues.

fragen.frage: The 'bg' (background) command moves a foreground process to the background.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'bg' moves a **stopped** process (which was stopped with Ctrl+Z) to the background. To send a foreground process directly to the background, append '&' to the end of the command.

fragen.frage: In a Bash script, comments can be introduced with a hash symbol (#).
fragen.erklaerung: True! Anything after a # (outside of a shebang) on a line is ignored by the interpreter. This is important for documenting and readability of scripts.

fragen.frage: The command 'hostname -I' displays all IP addresses of the local system.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-I' option (all IP addresses of the host interfaces) is useful for quickly getting an overview of all configured IP addresses.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/login.defs' file defines system-wide settings for creating new user accounts.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is where default values such as UID and GID ranges, minimum and maximum password aging, and the default UMASK are set, which are used when creating users with 'useradd'.

fragen.frage: A 'Virtual Machine' (VM) shares the host operating system's kernel with the host.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A VM virtualizes the entire hardware and has its own kernel and a complete guest operating system. Containers share the kernel with the host.

fragen.frage: The command 'mkfs -t ext4 /dev/sdb1' creates an ext4 filesystem on the /dev/sdb1 partition.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'mkfs' (make filesystem) is the command to format a partition or a disk with a specific filesystem. '-t' specifies the type of the filesystem.

fragen.frage: The 'boot process' of a Linux system begins with the BIOS/UEFI loading the bootloader (e.g., GRUB).
fragen.erklaerung: True! The bootloader is responsible for loading the kernel into memory and handing control over to it. Without a bootloader, the system cannot start.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/resolv.conf' file contains information about the DNS servers to be used.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This file is used by the C library to resolve hostnames to IP addresses. It is crucial for network functionality, especially for accessing the internet.

fragen.frage: To create a group, you use the command 'useradd -g GROUP GROUPNAME'.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The command to create a group is 'groupadd GROUPNAME'. 'useradd -g' is used to set the primary group for a new user.

fragen.frage: The 'du -sh /var/log' command displays the total size of the '/var/log' directory in human-readable format.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'du' (disk usage) with '-s' (summarize) and '-h' (human-readable) is ideal for quickly determining the disk space occupied by directories.

fragen.frage: The 'setgid' bit on a directory causes new files in that directory to automatically inherit the GID of the directory, instead of the GID of the user who created the file.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is useful in shared directories where all users working in that directory should create their files under the same group to facilitate collaboration.

fragen.frage: The 'top' command can be used to change the priority of a running process.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Within 'top', you can use the 'r' key (renice) to adjust the priority of a selected process, if you have the appropriate permissions.

fragen.frage: To start a loop in a Bash script, you use the keyword 'loop'.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Bash uses keywords like 'for', 'while', or 'until' to start loops. 'loop' is not a valid keyword in Bash for this purpose.

fragen.frage: The '/etc/hosts' file takes precedence over DNS for name resolution when configured locally.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Before a DNS server is queried, the system typically checks the '/etc/hosts' file. This is useful for local name resolution or to block certain domains.

fragen.frage: The command 'usermod -L USER' locks the user account so that the user can no longer log in.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-L' option locks the user's password by placing a '!' before the hash in /etc/shadow. This is a common method to temporarily disable a user's access.

fragen.frage: The 'initrd' (initial ramdisk) is a small, temporary root filesystem that is loaded before the actual root filesystem.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The initrd (or initramfs) contains necessary drivers and scripts to find and mount the actual root filesystem, especially if it is located on a complex storage device.

fragen.frage: A logical volume in LVM must always reside on a single physical hard drive.
fragen.erklaerung: False — One of the main advantages of LVM is the ability to span logical volumes across multiple physical hard drives or partitions (Physical Volumes). This offers great flexibility in storage management.

fragen.frage: The command 'kill -SIGTERM PID' is a hard kill and cannot be ignored.
fragen.erklaerung: False — SIGTERM (Signal 15) is a 'soft' kill that allows the process to terminate cleanly and can be ignored. SIGKILL (Signal 9) is the hard kill that cannot be ignored.

fragen.frage: In Bash, the exit status of the last executed command is stored in the special variable `$?`.
fragen.erklaerung: True! An exit status of 0 usually means success, while a non-zero value indicates an error. This is essential for error checking in scripts.

fragen.frage: The command 'firewall-cmd --add-port=80/tcp --permanent' permanently opens port 80 for TCP in firewalld.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '--permanent' option makes the rule persistent after a restart of the firewalld service or the system. Without it, the rule would only be valid until the next reboot.

fragen.frage: The default UMASK '022' means that new files and directories by default have full write permissions for all users.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A UMASK of '022' removes write permissions for group and others (2 for group, 2 for others). The effective permissions for a new file are 644 (rw-r--r--) and for a directory 755 (rwxr-xr-x).
